title: 104_hr925
content:
The "Private Property Protection Act of 1995" ensures that no law or agency action should diminish the value of privately owned property. Federal agencies must exercise their authority to prevent such limitations. Owners have the right to compensation for any loss of property value. The Federal Government must compensate property owners if an agency action diminishes the property's value by 20% or more. If the value decreases by over 50%, the government can buy the affected portion at fair market value. Once compensation is received, the property cannot be used against the agency's limitation, even if the action is later revoked. If the government action reduces property value by 20% or more, owners must be compensated. If the value drops by over 50%, the government can buy the affected portion at fair market value. Once compensation is given, the property cannot be used against the agency's limit, even if the action is later reversed. If the compensation is refunded to the Treasury adjusted for inflation, the property can be used. SEC. 4. EFFECT OF STATE LAW.

If a use is a nuisance or prohibited by local zoning, no compensation shall be made under this Act for that limitation.

SEC. 5. EXCEPTIONS.

No compensation for agency actions to prevent hazards to health, safety, or specific property, except for wetlands under the navigation servitude.

SEC. 6. PROCEDURE. An owner seeking compensation under this Act must make a written request to the agency within 180 days of receiving notice of the agency action. The agency can negotiate the compensation amount with the owner, and if no agreement is reached within 180 days, the owner can choose arbitration or a civil action for compensation. Arbitration procedures will be similar to those under title 9, United States Code. An owner seeking compensation under this Act must make a written request to the agency within 180 days. If no agreement is reached within 180 days, the owner can choose arbitration or a civil action for compensation. Arbitration procedures will be similar to those under title 9, United States Code. The agency shall promptly pay any award made to the owner in arbitration. An owner who does not choose arbitration or does not receive prompt payment may seek relief in a civil action against the agency. If successful, the owner is entitled to attorney's fees, litigation costs, and interest on the compensation amount. In a civil action under this section, the owner can obtain judgment against the agency, with payment made from the agency's annual appropriation. If the agency's action was due to another agency's requirement, partial or complete reimbursement can be sought. The agency head can transfer funds if needed, and if funds are insufficient, the agency must seek appropriation for the next fiscal year. SEC. 7. LIMITATION. Any payment under this Act by the United States is subject to appropriations. SEC. 8. DUTY OF NOTICE TO OWNERS. Agencies must notify property owners affected by limitations on property use and explain their rights to compensation. SEC. 9. RULES OF CONSTRUCTION. SEC. 9. RULES OF CONSTRUCTION. This Act does not limit any right to compensation under the Constitution or other US laws. Payment of compensation does not grant the Federal Government any additional rights except for use limitations resulting from agency action. The term "property" in this Act refers to land and the right to use or receive water. A use of property is limited by agency action if a legal right to use the property no longer exists due to the action. The term "agency action" includes making a grant to a public authority conditioned upon an action by the recipient that would be a limitation if done directly by the agency. The term "specified regulatory law" includes section 404 of the Federal Water Pollution Control Act. The Act limits property use based on specified laws, including the Endangered Species Act and the Reclamation Acts. The term "fair market value" is defined as the most probable price at which property would change hands in a competitive market. The term "State" includes the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, and other U.S. territories. The term "law of the State" includes laws of political subdivisions. The House of Representatives passed the bill on March 3, 1995. Attest: ROBIN H. CARLE, Clerk.
